title: Piecewise Planar and Non-Planar Stereo for Urban Scene Reconstruction

author: David Gallup, Department of Computer Science, University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill
category: Top->Computer Science->Computer Vision->Stereo & Structure from Motion

segmentation: Yes, so my talk is a piecewise planar and non planar stereo for urban scene reconstruction.
And the problem we are addressing is 3D reconstruction from video.
In this case we have streetside video of urban scenes and with the state of the art in computer vision.
At this point we can perform structure for motion and recover the camera poses and do stereo to recover dense 3D.
Depth Maps for for the scene and using those dense depth.
Depth measurements we can perform a 3D reconstruction and get a 3D model in the form of a textured polygonal mesh and the method we're using here is polyphase at all in AJC V 2008.

This method works quite well, it can produce can robustly produce 3D reconstructions over large scale for entire cities from video, and I'll point out a few of the errors though that we encounter in this type of reconstruction.

So in the first case.
We have errors due to specular surfaces like from glass on Windows and these errors are quite noticeable because they violate the brightness constancy assumptions in stereo.
We have other errors which are in a smaller scale but also equally noticeable and these are just due to the inherent uncertainty in depth measurements from stereo.
So in order to overcome these errors and get a better reconstruction, we need to use.
Additional information which we can incorporate in the form of priors so.
A very popular prior in stereo, of course, is the smoothness prior and in an urban scene, which we will be dealing with here.
We can have an even stricter prior, which is a planarity prior, so we will in this paper will be looking to reconstruct the scene as a. Piecewise planar reconstruction.
And we'll do this not just to get a more accurate reconstruction, but also to have a simplified geometry and lower complexity model.
So there is much work on piecewise planar stereo.
In 1999, Birchfield Intimacy presented a piecewise affine model for binocular stereo.
And in 2009, Cent had all presented a piecewise planar scene reconstruction method for an unordered set of photographs.
And also in 2009 for Kowa at all presented a stricter model in Manhattan world model that reconstructs the world as a set of orthogonal planes.
Now all of these methods work quite well and they all make one very strong assumption that the entire scene is peaceful.
Planner.
However, if we look at our data, we can see that there's quite a bit of the scene that is not piecewise planar, such as bushes, trees, and even quasi planar surfaces such as the grass.
So to address this type of scene, we will present a piecewise planar and non planar stereo reconstruction and I'll describe how how it works.
So we start with video.
We can use real time stereo to get a depth map an from that depth map.
We can perform ransack to detect a number of planes.
Then the goal is for every pixel in the image to label that pixel with one of the detected planes or the plane at Infinity.
Now up to this point, our model is very similar to related work, especially since at all.
So what we're going to do in contrast to related work, we're going to add a non plane label.
And the Non Plain label will represent a more general surface given by the original depth map.
We also have a discard label to discard pixels that cannot be reconstructed reliably.
So if we use this information to perform our segmentation, you'll see that planes here show up as colors and the non plane shows up as Gray and discarded pixels as black.
You'll see that the reconstruction is quite nice for the sorry, the segmentation is quite nice for the planar parts of the scene.
The back wall in the porch.
But for the non planar parts of the scene, although some are labeled with the non playing label, many are in fact labeled with planes.

Nevertheless and this is because planes in fact up to the uncertainty of stereo do indeed fit, these surface is quite well and using photo consistency alone it is impossible to tell whether these are planar or not.
So we need even more information.
So if we go back and look at our data again, we can see just from single images that we can tell quite reliably which parts of the scene are planar and which are not planar and.

If you look at why this is the case, you notice that the planar parts of the scene exhibit quite a regular texture and have lots of strong edges and lines and the non planer parts of the scene have a very irregular texture and color is also an important cue here.
So to capture this type of information.
Into our algorithm.

More recently in 2009, the classifier works as follows.
